attributes.title: Does complex PTSD predict and moderate trauma-focused treatment outcomes?

q1.value: Does  complex PTSD predict and moderate trauma-focused treatment outcomes?

q2.value: Chris Hoeboer, Rianne de Kleine, Maartje Schoorl, Danielle Oprel, Agnes van Minnen, Willem van der Does

q3.value: Project description: Previous studies indicated that a complex form of PTSD (CPTSD), characterized by disturbances in self-organization (DSO) alongside the core features of PTSD, might have important implications for treatment indications (e.g. Berliner et al., 2019; Brewin, 2019). In the current study, we investigated whether CPTSD diagnosis and severity of DSO predicted and moderated treatment outcomes of Prolonged Exposure (PE), intensified PE (iPE) and Skills Training in Affective and Interpersonal Regulation followed by PE (STAIR+PE) in 149 patients with childhood-abuse related PTSD.

q4.value:
1. We expect that both CPTSD diagnosis and higher DSO symptom severity predict worse treatment outcome (i.e. across conditions). 
2. we hypothesized that CPTSD diagnosis and DSO symptom severity moderate treatment outcome. We expect that CPTSD would be related to better treatment effects in STAIR+PE  in comparison to PE and intensive PE (iPE) in patients with childhood abuse-related PTSD.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: Note: Patients knew the condition, but the assessors did not.

question.value: 149 patients were randomized (1:1:1 ratio) to three conditions: PE, iPE or STAIR+PE.

q9.value: Randomization was carried out on study-enrolment by an independent researcher from Leiden University based on a computerized randomization sequence of permutated blocks of six participants stratified by gender.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: We did not use the predictor/moderator variables of this study in any analysis prior to this registration.

question.value: For information about the data collection procedures we refer to our design paper titled: Improving treatment for patients with childhood abuse related posttraumatic stress disorder (IMPACT study): protocol for a multicenter randomized trial comparing prolonged exposure with intensified prolonged exposure and phase-based treatment

q13.value: Out sample size consists of 149 patients

question.value: Treatment itself: PE, iPE or STAIR+PE
See design paper for all measures variables. See analysis plan for relevant variables for this paper.
We extract CPTSD diagnosis and DSO symptom severity using the International Trauma Questionnaire (ITQ).

q20.value: We will center predictor/moderator variables on an interval level to increase the interpretability of the results.

q21.value: Two-tailed p < .05 criteria. We will not adjust for multiple comparisons but we will report all statistical tests and consequences of the number of tests.

q22.value: We will include outliers in our analysis but check whether assumptions of analyses are met.  If serious problems occur we will perform clustered bootstrap to verify the results of the mixed-effect model.

q23.value: Missing data is handeled with maximum likelihood estimation so we use an intention to treat sample.

attributes.title: A terror management investigation of the implications of the novel coronavirus on death thought accessibility, health behavior intentions, and voting intentions
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

dataCollectionDates.value: To begin as soon as IRB review is complete, and ending upon target N achieved.

question2a.value:
Independent Variables: Mortality Salience Manipulation
- COVID-19 writing prompt (mortality proxy)
- Seasonal flu writing prompt (control)

question2b.value:
- Positive and Negative Affect
- Health Behavior Intentions
- Voting Intentions

question3b.value:
- Personal Need for Structure
- Big 5 Personality Traits
- Age
- State of Residence

question10b.value:
The study will be presented as a simple survey of "Health and Opinions" to reduce potential expectations as participants begin Participants first see an informed consent document. After consenting, participants are randomly counterbalanced in terms of order to see either the Personal Need for Structure (PNS) or Big Five Personality Inventory (Mini-IPIP) first. The PNS is a validated measure of a dispositional desire for order and structure in everyday life, composed of 12 items (e.g., "I find that a consistent routine enables me to enjoy life more"), measured on a 5-point Likert-type scale (1 = "Strongly disagree" - 5 = "Strongly agree"). The Mini-IPIP is a shorter measure of the dispositional Big Five Traits of Intellect (e.g., "I have a vivid imagination"), Extraversion (e.g., "I am the life of the party"), Agreeableness (e.g., "I sympathize with others' feelings"), Conscientiousness (e.g., "I like order"), and Neuroticism (e.g., "I get upset easily"), measured on the same Likert scale as the PNS.  
After the PNS and Big Five, participants are presented with the mortality salience manipulation. This manipulation is patterned after standard mortality salience manipulations commonly used in terror management research, where participants are asked to "jot down [their] thoughts and feelings related to your own death" (compared to a control condition in which participants write about experiencing dental pain, which is negatively-valanced but unrelated to mortality). However, in the present study, these manipulations employ either mention of COVID-19 (serving as the mortality prime, due to current circumstances) or the seasonal flu (a similar issue, but less related to mortality). Participants are randomly assigned to one of these two writing prompts, double blindly, through random assignment in the Qualtrics system. 
Following the mortality salience manipulation, the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS-X) will be presented. Traditional terror management research utilizes the PANAS-X as a distraction task during which the thoughts associated with mortality become less conscious (i.e., distal). This task will serve as such, but will also be analyzed to examine the extent to which negative affective states (especially anxiety) are instigated by COVID-19 priming. Additionally, an attention-check item ("For this item, please select "extremely") is embedded within the 60-item, 5-point Likert scale (1= Mot at all - 5 = Extremely).
After the PANAS-X, death-thought accessibility will be measured using another standard terror management measure: a wordstem completion task. Out of 25 presented wordstems, 6 can be spelled with either neutral words, or words related to mortality. Participants will see some letters and asked to fill in the remaining blanks as quickly as possible; for example, "C O F F __ __", which can be completed as either "COFFEE" or "COFFIN". The number of mortality-completed words are then tallied. Additionally, this task is timed, allowing for potential screening and other analyses to examine how long participants take to consider each word.
After DTA, participants are presented with a novel measure of flu-related health behaviors. The behaviors themselves are those listed by the Centers for Disease Control as helpful in containing the spread of the flu (e.g., washing hands for 20 seconds). Participants are asked to rate the extent to which they can imagine themselves engaging in the listed behaviors on a 5-point Likert scale (1 = Not at all - 5 = Entirely).
Then, participants are presented with a measure of voting intentions pertaining to the upcoming November 2020 election. They are asked to characterize their political ideology, strength of ideology, party affiliation, intended candidate, and level of confidence in their intended candidate. 
Finally, standard demographic questions are presented. Within the demographics, a manipulation check is presented to ensure that participants remembered the prompt with which they were presented, along with short probing questions (e.g., "Do you have any thoughts or feelings about this study").
At the very end, participants are debriefed and thanked for their participation.

question4b.value: Sample will be selected from Amazon MTurk workers who live in the United States and have objectively high reviews based on MTurk metrics (e.g., high HIT completion rate).

question5b.value: Data will be collected through the Amazon MTurk system. MTurk workers meeting the above criteria will be eligible. After signing up for the HIT, workers will be redirected to a Qualtrics link through which the study will be administered.

question6b.value: For a planned effect size of .20, power analyses prescribe a rounded number of about 50 participants per condition. There are only two conditions, but due to a variety of anticipated moderators and mediators, as well as anticipated attrition and bot-related activities, we will collect data from 200 MTurk workers.

question7b.value: When data collection reaches 200 participants, data will be visibly scanned to approximate the number of complete responses. MTurk is notoriously finicky and may include potential bots. If data appear non-bot completed and to generally include complete responses, data collection will be terminated when 200 responses are collected.

question8b.value: Geolocation services will restrict participation to the continental United States. Those who fail an attention check item embedded within the PANAS-X (e.g., "For this item, please select extremely") will be excluded. Those who fail a manipulation check item (e.g., "Please select the topic that best describes the writing prompt you completed earlier in the study") will be excluded. Those who take too long on the entire study (more than 60 minutes) will first be assessed for data quality and excluded when appropriate.

question9b.value: Due to the straightforward nature of this study, we do not anticipate stopping this study for any reason. If some mistake is made, we will stop data collection and restart from scratch.

question1a.value:
The COVID-19 prime will elicit higher death-thought accessibility (DTA) compared to the seasonal flu.

The COVID-19 prime will elicit a more compliance with the CDC-recommended health behavior intentions (e.g., washing hands) than the seasonal flu.

The COVID-19 prime will elicit more left-leaning political voting intentions (controlling for political orientation) than the seasonal flu.

Increases in DTA as a function of the COVID-19 prime will mediate health behavior and voting intentions.


The COVID-19 prime will interact with personal need for structure (PNS), such that individuals high in PNS will response to the COVID-19 prime with greater DTA than individuals low in PNS.

The COVID-19 prime will interact with PNS, such that individuals high in PNS will response to the COVID-19 prime more compliance with the CDC-recommended health behavior than individuals low in PNS.

The COVID-19 prime will interact with PNS, such that individuals high in PNS will response to the COVID-19 prime more left-leaning political voting intentions (controlling for political orientation) behavior than individuals low in PNS.

Increases in DTA as a function of the COVID-19 prime and PNS interaction will mediate health behavior and voting intentions.

We intend to explore the impact of Big 5 Personality Traits (especially neuroticism and extraversion) as other potential moderators in the same fashion as PNS. For extraversion, we expect the results on health behavior to be specific to those that do not involve social distancing.

question3a.value: A manipulation check in the form of a three-option multiple choice question imploring them to select the writing prompt they saw toward the beginning of the study (Seasonal Influenza, COVID-19, or H1N1 Swine Flue). Those who select the incorrect option, or select H1N1 at all, will be excluded from data analyses.

question5a.value: Research from Sole (2007) indicates that priming the idea of a pandemic produces death-related fear and behavior intentions in a manner comparable to traditional terror management mortality salience priming. The current climate of American health surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic is timely and relevant to terror management theorizing, especially in relation to health behaviors and upcoming political events (i.e., the 2020 Presidential election).

question1c.value: The COVID-19 prime will elicit higher death-thought accessibility (DTA) compared to the seasonal flu.

question2c.value: A one-way between-subjects ANOVA will assess mean differences in death-thought accessibility between the COVID-19 and seasonal flu primes. F-test statistics, effect size, and p-values will be used to test for the presence of an effect of mortality salience on death-thought accessibility.

question3c.value:
IV: Mortality priming (COVID-19 vs. flu)
DV: Death-thought accessibility
Covariates: Age, positive and negative affect, personal need for structure, Big 5 traits

question4c.value: Each covariate used for this prediction will account for the potential impact of what we anticipate will be additional variables that may impact death-thought accessibility; this method will give us the clearest idea of the impact of mortality priming alone on death-thought accessibility.

question5c.value: Null hypothesis testing will be utilized.

question1c.value:
The COVID-19 prime will elicit more left-leaning political voting intentions (controlling for political orientation) than the seasonal flu.

Political affiliation and voting intentions are assessed using face-valid questions about political party identification, left- versus right-leaning ideology (using a 7-point Likert scale, where 1 = "Far Left" and 7 = "Far Right"), explicit voting intentions (Biden, Sanders, Trump, write-in candidates), and level of confidence in their chosen candidate (4 face-valid items, "How much confidence do you have in your candidate", on a 5-point Likert scale, to be compiled into an average composite score if appropriate based on Cronbach alpha score).

question2c.value:
A one-way between-subjects ANOVA will assess mean differences in voting intentions between the COVID-19 and seasonal flu primes. F-test statistics, effect size, and p-values will be used to test for the presence of an effect of mortality salience on voting intentions.

A PROCESS Model 4 technique will be used to investigate the mediating effect of death-thought accessibility on left-leaning political voting intentions (controlling for political orientation) following the COVID-19 prime. An examination of effects and p-values along the pathways will determine the presence or absence of an effect.

question3c.value:
IV: Mortality salience manipulation
DV: Voting intentions
Covariates: Age, positive and negative affect, Big 5 traits, DTA, health behavior intentions, state of residence, political orientation

question4c.value: Each included covariate will control for potential third variable problems (especially political orientation) to isolate the effect of mortality salience priming alone on voting intentions.

question1c.value: Increases in DTA as a function of the COVID-19 prime will mediate health behavior and voting intentions.

question2c.value: A PROCESS Model 4 will be utilized to test the mediation effect of DTA on death thought accessibility and health behavior intentions.

question3c.value:
IV: Mortality salience manipulation
Moderator: PNS
Mediator: DTA
DV: Health behavior intentions
Covariates: Age, Big 5 traits, positive and negative affect.

question1c.value: The COVID-19 prime will elicit a more compliance with the CDC-recommended health behavior intentions (e.g., washing hands) than the seasonal flu.

question2c.value:
A one-way between-subjects ANOVA will assess mean differences in health behavior intentions between the COVID-19 and seasonal flu primes. F-test statistics, effect size, and p-values will be used to test for the presence of an effect of mortality salience on health behavior intentions.

A PROCESS Model 4 technique will be used to investigate the mediating effect of death-thought accessibility on health behavior intentions following the COVID-19 prime. An examination of effects and p-values along the pathways will determine the presence or absence of an effect.

question3c.value:
IV: Mortality salience manipulation
DV: Health behavior intentions
Covariates: Age, positive and negative affect, personal need for structure, Big 5 traits, DTA

question4c.value: Each included covariate will help to isolate mean differences in health behavior intentions as a function of mortality salience priming.

question1c.value:
The COVID-19 prime will interact with personal need for structure (PNS), such that individuals high in PNS will response to the COVID-19 prime with greater DTA than individuals low in PNS.
The COVID-19 prime will interact with PNS, such that individuals high in PNS will response to the COVID-19 prime more compliance with the CDC-recommended health behavior than individuals low in PNS.
The COVID-19 prime will interact with PNS, such that individuals high in PNS will response to the COVID-19 prime more left-leaning political voting intentions (controlling for political orientation) behavior than individuals low in PNS.

Increases in DTA as a function of the COVID-19 prime and PNS interaction will mediate health behavior and voting intentions.

We intend to explore the impact of Big 5 Personality Traits (especially neuroticism and extraversion) as other potential moderators in the same fashion as PNS.

question2c.value: Appropriate Process Models will be utilized to examine mediation, moderation, and moderated mediation where appropriate.

question3c.value:
IV: Mortality salience manipulation
DVs: DTA, health behavior intentions, voting intentions
Mediators: DTA (when examining health behavior intentions and voting intentions)
Moderators: PNS, Big 5 Traits
Covariates: Political affiliation, Age

registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
The study will be presented as a simple survey of "Health and Opinions" to reduce potential expectations as participants begin Participants first see an informed consent document. After consenting, participants are randomly counterbalanced in terms of order to see either the Personal Need for Structure (PNS) or Big Five Personality Inventory (Mini-IPIP) first. The PNS is a validated measure of a dispositional desire for order and structure in everyday life, composed of 12 items (e.g., "I find that a consistent routine enables me to enjoy life more"), measured on a 5-point Likert-type scale (1 = "Strongly disagree" - 5 = "Strongly agree"). The Mini-IPIP is a shorter measure of the dispositional Big Five Traits of Intellect (e.g., "I have a vivid imagination"), Extraversion (e.g., "I am the life of the party"), Agreeableness (e.g., "I sympathize with others' feelings"), Conscientiousness (e.g., "I like order"), and Neuroticism (e.g., "I get upset easily"), measured on the same Likert scale as the PNS.  
After the PNS and Big Five, participants are presented with the mortality salience manipulation. This manipulation is patterned after standard mortality salience manipulations commonly used in terror management research, where participants are asked to "jot down [their] thoughts and feelings related to your own death" (compared to a control condition in which participants write about experiencing dental pain, which is negatively-valanced but unrelated to mortality). However, in the present study, these manipulations employ either mention of COVID-19 (serving as the mortality prime, due to current circumstances) or the seasonal flu (a similar issue, but less related to mortality). Participants are randomly assigned to one of these two writing prompts, double blindly, through random assignment in the Qualtrics system. 
Following the mortality salience manipulation, the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS-X) will be presented. Traditional terror management research utilizes the PANAS-X as a distraction task during which the thoughts associated with mortality become less conscious (i.e., distal). This task will serve as such, but will also be analyzed to examine the extent to which negative affective states (especially anxiety) are instigated by COVID-19 priming. Additionally, an attention-check item ("For this item, please select "extremely") is embedded within the 60-item, 5-point Likert scale (1= Mot at all - 5 = Extremely).
After the PANAS-X, death-thought accessibility will be measured using another standard terror management measure: a wordstem completion task. Out of 25 presented wordstems, 6 can be spelled with either neutral words, or words related to mortality. Participants will see some letters and asked to fill in the remaining blanks as quickly as possible; for example, "C O F F __ __", which can be completed as either "COFFEE" or "COFFIN". The number of mortality-completed words are then tallied. Additionally, this task is timed, allowing for potential screening and other analyses to examine how long participants take to consider each word.
After DTA, participants are presented with a novel measure of flu-related health behaviors. The behaviors themselves are those listed by the Centers for Disease Control as helpful in containing the spread of the flu (e.g., washing hands for 20 seconds). Participants are asked to rate the extent to which they can imagine themselves engaging in the listed behaviors on a 5-point Likert scale (1 = Not at all - 5 = Entirely).
Then, participants are presented with a measure of voting intentions pertaining to the upcoming November 2020 election. They are asked to characterize their political ideology, strength of ideology, party affiliation, intended candidate, and level of confidence in their intended candidate. 
Finally, standard demographic questions are presented. Within the demographics, a manipulation check is presented to ensure that participants remembered the prompt with which they were presented, along with short probing questions (e.g., "Do you have any thoughts or feelings about this study").
At the very end, participants are debriefed and thanked for their participation.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: The COVID-19 prime will elicit higher death-thought accessibility (DTA) compared to the seasonal flu.

A one-way between-subjects ANOVA will assess mean differences in death-thought accessibility between the COVID-19 and seasonal flu primes. F-test statistics, effect size, and p-values will be used to test for the presence of an effect of mortality salience on death-thought accessibility.

IV: Mortality priming (COVID-19 vs. flu)
DV: Death-thought accessibility
Covariates: Age, positive and negative affect, personal need for structure, Big 5 traits

Each covariate used for this prediction will account for the potential impact of what we anticipate will be additional variables that may impact death-thought accessibility; this method will give us the clearest idea of the impact of mortality priming alone on death-thought accessibility.
Null hypothesis testing will be utilized.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi:
The COVID-19 prime will elicit more left-leaning political voting intentions (controlling for political orientation) than the seasonal flu.

Political affiliation and voting intentions are assessed using face-valid questions about political party identification, left- versus right-leaning ideology (using a 7-point Likert scale, where 1 = "Far Left" and 7 = "Far Right"), explicit voting intentions (Biden, Sanders, Trump, write-in candidates), and level of confidence in their chosen candidate (4 face-valid items, "How much confidence do you have in your candidate", on a 5-point Likert scale, to be compiled into an average composite score if appropriate based on Cronbach alpha score).

A one-way between-subjects ANOVA will assess mean differences in voting intentions between the COVID-19 and seasonal flu primes. F-test statistics, effect size, and p-values will be used to test for the presence of an effect of mortality salience on voting intentions.

A PROCESS Model 4 technique will be used to investigate the mediating effect of death-thought accessibility on left-leaning political voting intentions (controlling for political orientation) following the COVID-19 prime. An examination of effects and p-values along the pathways will determine the presence or absence of an effect.

IV: Mortality salience manipulation
DV: Voting intentions
Covariates: Age, positive and negative affect, Big 5 traits, DTA, health behavior intentions, state of residence, political orientation
Each included covariate will control for potential third variable problems (especially political orientation) to isolate the effect of mortality salience priming alone on voting intentions.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Sample will be selected from Amazon MTurk workers who live in the United States and have objectively high reviews based on MTurk metrics (e.g., high HIT completion rate).

Data will be collected through the Amazon MTurk system. MTurk workers meeting the above criteria will be eligible. After signing up for the HIT, workers will be redirected to a Qualtrics link through which the study will be administered.

For a planned effect size of .20, power analyses prescribe a rounded number of about 50 participants per condition. There are only two conditions, but due to a variety of anticipated moderators and mediators, as well as anticipated attrition and bot-related activities, we will collect data from 200 MTurk workers.

When data collection reaches 200 participants, data will be visibly scanned to approximate the number of complete responses. MTurk is notoriously finicky and may include potential bots. If data appear non-bot completed and to generally include complete responses, data collection will be terminated when 200 responses are collected.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-fourth.fourth.ques: Increases in DTA as a function of the COVID-19 prime will mediate health behavior and voting intentions.
A PROCESS Model 4 will be utilized to test the mediation effect of DTA on death thought accessibility and health behavior intentions.

IV: Mortality salience manipulation
Moderator: PNS
Mediator: DTA
DV: Health behavior intentions
Covariates: Age, Big 5 traits, positive and negative affect.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques: The COVID-19 prime will elicit a more compliance with the CDC-recommended health behavior intentions (e.g., washing hands) than the seasonal flu.

A one-way between-subjects ANOVA will assess mean differences in health behavior intentions between the COVID-19 and seasonal flu primes. F-test statistics, effect size, and p-values will be used to test for the presence of an effect of mortality salience on health behavior intentions.

A PROCESS Model 4 technique will be used to investigate the mediating effect of death-thought accessibility on health behavior intentions following the COVID-19 prime. An examination of effects and p-values along the pathways will determine the presence or absence of an effect.

IV: Mortality salience manipulation
DV: Health behavior intentions
Covariates: Age, positive and negative affect, personal need for structure, Big 5 traits, DTA
Each included covariate will help to isolate mean differences in health behavior intentions as a function of mortality salience priming.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-further.further.qu:
The COVID-19 prime will interact with personal need for structure (PNS), such that individuals high in PNS will response to the COVID-19 prime with greater DTA than individuals low in PNS.
The COVID-19 prime will interact with PNS, such that individuals high in PNS will response to the COVID-19 prime more compliance with the CDC-recommended health behavior than individuals low in PNS.
The COVID-19 prime will interact with PNS, such that individuals high in PNS will response to the COVID-19 prime more left-leaning political voting intentions (controlling for political orientation) behavior than individuals low in PNS.

Increases in DTA as a function of the COVID-19 prime and PNS interaction will mediate health behavior and voting intentions.

We intend to explore the impact of Big 5 Personality Traits (especially neuroticism and extraversion) as other potential moderators in the same fashion as PNS.
Appropriate Process Models will be utilized to examine mediation, moderation, and moderated mediation where appropriate.

IV: Mortality salience manipulation
DVs: DTA, health behavior intentions, voting intentions
Mediators: DTA (when examining health behavior intentions and voting intentions)
Moderators: PNS, Big 5 Traits
Covariates: Political affiliation, Age
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: Geolocation services will restrict participation to the continental United States. Those who fail an attention check item embedded within the PANAS-X (e.g., "For this item, please select extremely") will be excluded. Those who fail a manipulation check item (e.g., "Please select the topic that best describes the writing prompt you completed earlier in the study") will be excluded. Those who take too long on the entire study (more than 60 minutes) will first be assessed for data quality and excluded when appropriate.

attributes.title: Coronavirus and Eating Behaviors
attributes.description: Survey study on eating and drinking behaviors during the coronavirus pandemic

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Coronavirus and Eating Behaviors Study Description

other.value:
We will measure the following demographics: age, gender, race/ethnicity, highest level of education, household income, and height and weight (to calculate BMI). 

We will test whether the cohorts obtained during March 2020 and February 2019 differ with regards to demographic representation. 

We will include the following items for exploratory purposes: “During the past 7 days, how many days have you engaged in at least 30 minutes of exercise, to the point of being at least moderately out of breath?" “During the past 7 days, how aware have you been of the policies regarding the coronavirus pandemic issued by the state you reside in?" "During the past 7 days, how much have you been abiding by the policies regarding the coronavirus pandemic issued by the state you reside in?" “How vulnerable do you feel to getting coronavirus?” “If you were to get coronavirus, how vulnerable do you feel to being seriously ill or dying from coronavirus?” “Have you been tested for coronavirus?” “Were your test results positive or negative for coronavirus?” “Have you been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for coronavirus?” 

We will include the following item for exploratory purposes: “During the past 7 days, what kinds of food have you been eating?” (*open-ended question)

sample.value: We will collect a sample size of 1000 participants. Our sample size was based on available research funds.

analyses.value:
All variables will be assessed for normality (i.e., skew, kurtosis). Transformations (e.g., natural log transformation) will be considered for non-normal variables (i.e., skew greater than |1|, kurtosis greater than |3|). 

For Aim 1, we will conduct one-sample t tests comparing the dependent variables obtained from the March 2020 cohort to the averages of the dependent variables obtained from the February 2019 cohort. 

For Aims 2 and 2a, we will conduct multiple regressions predicting dependent variables from independent variables and potential moderators (main effect and interaction with corona-related distress).

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants from analysis if at least one of the following criteria is met:
(1) The participant does not follow study instructions
(2) The participant completes the study in < 3 minutes
(3) The participant reports improbable values for adult height and weight
(4) The participant incorrectly answers quality control questions at the end of the study

We will not exclude outliers in primary analysis.

dependent.value:
INDEPENDENT VARIABLE
Coronavirus-related Distress will be assessed with a modified version of the Impact of Events Scale.

DEPENDENT VARIABLES
Added Sugars Intake and Fruits and Vegetables Intake will be assessed with the National Cancer Institute’s Dietary Screener Questionnaire.

Food Addiction Symptoms will be assessed with the mYFAS 2.0. This version of the mYFAS 2.0 will be modified to ask about symptoms in the past month.

Eating to Cope will be assessed with the Coping subscale of the Palatable Eating Motives Scale. This version of the Palatable Eating Motives Scale will be modified to ask about eating to cope in the past 7 days.

Drinking Frequency and Quantity will be assessed with the following items: “During the past 7 days, how many days did you consume alcohol?” “On a typical day during the past 7 days, how much alcohol did you consume?” (*1-drink equivalent images are shown to participants)

Drinking to Cope will be assessed with the Coping subscale of the Drinking Motives Questionnaire-Revised. This version of the Drinking Motives Questionnaire-Revised will be modified to ask about drinking to cope in the past 7 days. 

Cooking Behaviors will be assessed with frequency items adapted from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey. 

POTENTIAL MODERATORS
State of current residence will be measured with the item "In which state do you currently reside?"

Perceived vulnerability to disease will be measured with the Perceived Vulnerability to Disease Scale.

Political orientation will be measured with the item "Generally speaking, do you usually think of yourself as a Republican, Democrat, an Independent, or something else?"

Age will be measured with the item "How old are you in years?"

Gender will be measured with the item “Which term BEST describes your gender? Check all that apply.”

conditions.value: This is a non-experimental study so participants will not be assigned to conditions.

hypothesis.value:
Aim 1:  To investigate cohort effects in (1) added sugars intake, (2) fruits and vegetables intake, (3) food addiction symptoms, (4) eating to cope, and (5) perceived vulnerability to disease between MTurk samples collected in February 2019 and March 2020. 

Hypothesis 1: The March 2020 cohort compared to the February 2019 cohort will show greater added sugars intake, less fruits and vegetables intake, greater food addiction symptoms, greater eating to cope, and greater perceived vulnerability to disease.

Aim 2: To investigate associations between coronavirus-related distress and (1) added sugars intake, (2) fruits and vegetables intake, (3) food addiction symptoms, (4) eating to cope, (5) drinking frequency and quantity, (6) drinking to cope, and (7) cooking behaviors. 

Hypothesis 2: Coronavirus-related distress will be positively associated with added sugars intake, food addiction symptoms, eating to cope, drinking frequency and quantity, and drinking to cope. Coronavirus-related distress will be negatively associated with fruits and vegetables intake, and cooking behaviors.

Aim 2a: To test potential moderators of Aim 2 including state of current residence, perceived vulnerability to disease, political orientation, age, and gender. 

Hypothesis 2a: The positive associations between coronavirus-related distress and added sugars intake, food addiction symptoms, eating to cope, drinking frequency and quantity, and drinking to cope will be stronger among those residing in states that have implemented stay-at-home policies, those higher in perceived vulnerability to disease, Democrats, and older adults. The negative association between coronavirus-related distress and fruit and vegetable intake and cooking behaviors will be stronger among those residing in states that have implemented stay-at-home policies, those higher in perceived vulnerability to disease, Democrats, and older adults. 

For gender, the positive associations between coronavirus-related distress and added sugars intake, food addiction symptoms, and eating to cope will be stronger among women whereas the positive associations between coronavirus-related distress and drinking frequency and quantity and drinking to cope will be stronger among men.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

attributes.title: Attitudes Towards Immigrants in Denmark
attributes.description:
This preregistration form was created on the 27th of March 2020. 

The form consists of a description of the aim of our study and research design. Furthermore, we present our hypotheses  and the plan for the data collection. 

This form was registered before the data collection began. 

In the attached file we provide an overview of the attributes and levels of our conjoint profiles.

This research project is conducted by Emil Teddy Stachurska and Jens Claudi, University of Copenhagen.

summary.value:
Introduction  
Our ambition with this study is to investigate how economic and cultural characteristics among immigrant profiles affects individuals’ preferences on whom to admit into Denmark.   

In this preregistration form, we present our research design, our hypotheses and the plan for the data collection process.  

This study has been preregistered before the data collection has begun.   

Research design  
We employ a conjoint analysis on a Danish representative sample of 1,000 respondents to test our hypotheses.  

Our experimental approach is two-folded:  
First, we present respondents for two immigrant profiles that can potentially vary on 7 different characteristics (gender, age, education level, former profession, language skills, country of origin and religion).  We then force the respondents to choose between the two immigrants on whom to allow into Denmark. After this, respondents are asked to rate their preference for allowing each of the immigrants into Denmark. The forced choice and the rating task are defined as one conjoint task. There are 5 conjoint tasks in total. 

Following the 5 conjoint tasks, we randomize the respondents into two groups containing 500 respondents each. Each group will be asked a question that aims to prime different aspects of the threat that immigration might pose to the majority group. Group 1 will be asked a question that highlights cultural threat and group 2 will be asked a question that highlights economic threat. Cultural and economic threat are some of the main explanations of attitudes towards immigrants, and our aim is to investigate whether the “nature of the threat” can prime certain characteristics in a conjoint experiment.  

After the two groups have been primed, we once again give the respondents 5 conjoint tasks as described above. This means that the total number of conjoint tasks is 10.  

By doing this, we construct a priming experiment with two treatments groups “inside” our conjoint experiment. This makes it possible for us to make our analysis with-in subjects (before and after prime) as well as between subjects (the two priming groups). Thus, the respondent’s answers to the conjoint task before the prime act as the control group and we can compare immigrant preferences with-in the same subjects. 

The attributes and levels for the conjoint profiles are available in the attached file. 

Hypotheses 

In this study, we work with three separate hypotheses: the hierarchy hypothesis, the consensus hypothesis and the perception-of-threat hypothesis. The three hypotheses are not mutually exclusive and our aim is not to test which of these has the most explanatory power.  
 
The hierarchy hypothesis:  

Expectation: Danes do not support the admission of immigrants whose country of origin is culturally more distant. 

Based on social identity theory and theories on ethnic hierarchies, we expect that immigrants whose country of origin is more culturally distant from the majority population will have a lower probability of being admitted into Denmark. For instance, we expect that immigrants from Germany and Poland will have a higher probability of admission compared to immigrants from Somalia, Syria and Iraq.  

The consensus hypothesis:  

Expectation: Danes prefer immigrants with higher education – regardless of their own educational background. 

The literature on economic threat posed by immigration highlights that labor market competition is one of the main explanations of attitudes towards immigrants. However, recent studies have criticized these findings.  

Perception-of-threat hypothesis:  
Expectation: (A) If cultural aspects of the threat of immigrants in Denmark is made salient, cultural characteristics matter more. (B) If economic aspects of the threat of immigrants in Denmark is made salient, economic characteristics matter more.  

We expect that respondents will chance their preferences for certain characteristics among the immigrant profiles are primed. Priming the “nature of the threat” will so to speak bring certain characteristics top of mind among respondents and make them more aware of certain characteristics in the conjoint tasks.  

Plan for data collection and pre-analysis  
Epinion carries out the data collection and participants are recruited through the representative Audience Project panel. The final sample size will be 1,000 respondents.   

The data collection process will start on 27/3-2020 and run for approximately 2 weeks or until we reach the desired sample size.

Introduction  
Our ambition with this study is to investigate how economic and cultural characteristics among immigrant profiles affects individuals’ preferences on whom to admit into Denmark.   

In this preregistration form, we present our research design, our hypotheses and the plan for the data collection process.

Hypotheses

For instance, we expect that immigrants from Germany and Poland will have a higher probability of admission compared to immigrants from Somalia, Syria and Iraq.

The literature on economic threat posed by immigration highlights that labor market competition is one of the main explanations of attitudes towards immigrants. However, recent studies have criticized these findings.  

Perception-of-threat hypothesis:  
Expectation: (A) If cultural aspects of the threat of immigrants in Denmark is made salient, cultural characteristics matter more. (B) If economic aspects of the threat of immigrants in Denmark is made salient, economic characteristics matter more.  

We expect that respondents will chance their preferences for certain characteristics among the immigrant profiles are primed. The data collection process will start on 27/3-2020 and run for approximately 2 weeks or until we reach the desired sample size.

attributes.title: Moving in Unison after perceptual interruption
attributes.description: Humans interact in groups through various perception and action channels. The continuity of interaction despite a transient loss of perceptual contact often exists and contributes to goal achievement. Here, we study the dynamics of this continuity, in two experiments involving participants (N=7) synchronizing their movements in space and in time. We show that behavioural unison can be maintained after perceptual contact has been lost, for about 7s. Agent similarity and spatial configuration in the group modulated synchronization performance, differently so when perceptual interaction was present or when it was memorized. Modelling these data through a network of oscillators enabled us to clarify the double origin of this memory effect, of individual and social nature. These results shed new light into why humans continue to move in unison after perceptual interruption, and are consequential for a wide variety of applications at work, in art and in sport.

summary.value: The project contains data from two behavioral experiments performed at EuroMov, University of Montpellier, on group synchronization during and after visual interaction.

registration_responses.summary: The project contains data from two behavioral experiments performed at EuroMov, University of Montpellier, on group synchronization during and after visual interaction.

attributes.title: The role of the Executive Director of Nursing in the UK: A Scoping Review Protocol
attributes.description: The role of the Executive Director of Nursing in the UK: A Scoping review protocol

summary.value:
This is a registration for a scoping review protocol (see attached document). This scoping review protocol sets out plans to locate, examine and describe the literature on the distinctive contemporary challenges and opportunities facing those responsible for leading nursing services in the UK at the executive board level. The role of the Executive Nurse Director in the UK has a small evidence base, it is important to examine this role in order to provide a greater evidence-base for future training and development opportunities. 
At the present date, the authors are not aware of any other registrations on this topic.

registration_responses.summary:

This scoping review protocol sets out plans to locate, examine and describe the literature on the distinctive contemporary challenges and opportunities facing those responsible for leading nursing services in the UK at the executive board level. At the present date, the authors are not aware of any other registrations on this topic.

attributes.title: Outcomes Evaluation of the Pathways from Prison to Postsecondary Education RCT
attributes.description: This project is an evaluation of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of the Pathways from Prison to Postsecondary Education program, a prison-based correctional education program designed to increase inmates’ likelihood of attaining a postsecondary degree and reduce their likelihood of recidivating after their release. The Pathways program partners with local colleges and universities to provide inmates with (i) in-prison postsecondary education at least two years prior to release, and (ii) two years of post-release support in entering college and completing their postsecondary education.

summary.value: This project is an outcomes evaluation of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of the Pathways from Prison to Postsecondary Education program, a prison-based correctional education program designed to increase inmates’ likelihood of attaining a postsecondary degree and reduce their likelihood of recidivating after their release. The randomized sample comprised 426 prisoners in Michigan and North Carolina. Inmates were randomly assigned to either (i) a treatment group that received the Pathways program, or (ii) a control group that did not, but could participate in college correspondence courses and/or prison-based career and technical education programs. The study will measure the impact of the program on enrollment in a postsecondary institution and recidivism four years after random assignment (or approximately two years after prisoners’ scheduled release date).

registration_responses.summary: This project is an outcomes evaluation of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of the Pathways from Prison to Postsecondary Education program, a prison-based correctional education program designed to increase inmates’ likelihood of attaining a postsecondary degree and reduce their likelihood of recidivating after their release. The randomized sample comprised 426 prisoners in Michigan and North Carolina. Inmates were randomly assigned to either (i) a treatment group that received the Pathways program, or (ii) a control group that did not, but could participate in college correspondence courses and/or prison-based career and technical education programs. The study will measure the impact of the program on enrollment in a postsecondary institution and recidivism four years after random assignment (or approximately two years after prisoners’ scheduled release date).

attributes.title: Professional identity formation within longitudinal integrated clerkships: a scoping review.
attributes.description:
Professional identity formation within longitudinal integrated clerkships: a scoping review. 

A scoping review exploring what is known about professional identity formation and development within longitudinal integrated clerkships (LICs).

summary.value: This registration contains a scoping review protocol for the planned review: Professional Identity formation within longitudinal integrated clerkships. There are no prior registrations of this project.

registration_responses.summary: This registration contains a scoping review protocol for the planned review: Professional Identity formation within longitudinal integrated clerkships. There are no prior registrations of this project.

attributes.title: Social Cost and Political Gain: The Effect of Mislabeling COVID-19 as "Chinese Virus"

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Social Cost and Political Gain: The Effect of Mislabeling COVID-19 as “Chinese Virus”
We examine whether mislabeling COVID-19 as "Chinese Virus" leads to 1) more social stigmatization; 2) less social pressure of stigmatization; 3) less blame toward the federal government.

other.value:
A.	Subgroup analysis
We will subgroup our sample into three groups: “Trump approve”, “Trump disapprove” and “Trump no opinion”. We will rerun the main analyses in each subgroup. 
B.	Covariate analysis
1.	[Blame] explain correlations between control variables and blame in the “blame model”. 
2.	[Direct] explain correlations between control variables and driect “Agree” in the “direct model”. 
3.	We will compare results for who passes or failed the manipulation check question. 
C.	Re-weighted analysis
We will weight our data with iterative proportional fitting technique (raking) to match the US population. We will compare results for the original data and the weighted data.

sample.value: We will stop data collection once 1,200 subjects (approximately 300 per cell) have submitted a response on MTurk. Deviations from this goal are entirely due to MTurk software and outside of our control.

analyses.value:
Our analysis separate in three parts: blame, social stigmatization, and social desirability effect. 
	Blame
	The Average Treatment effect (ATE) will be visualized by a difference-in-means graphic.
	State fixed effect linear model with control covariates and clustered standard errors at the State level (“blame model”). 
	Stigmatization (answering “Agree” in the sensitive statement)
	[Direct Question] We use difference-in-means to examine the Chinese Virus treatment effect on the direct question. We will also report the percentage of answering “Agree” in the direct question. Finally, we will report a logit regression model with covariates (“direct model”). 
	[List item count] We will report ATE with difference-in-means between the 4-item list and 3-item list in both control and Chinese Virus treatment groups. 
	Social desirability effect (Coffman et al. 2017)
We subgroup our sample by control and Chinese Virus treatment groups. The following analysis will be done in both groups. We will compare results for both groups. 
	[Change in sensitive “Agree”] We observe direct question answer as d_i (0,1), and 3-item count answer as c_i (between 0 to 3). We measure the sum of both questions as y_i^D=d_i+c_i. We measure the 4-item count answer with one sensitive statement as y_i^S (between 0 to 4). Ideally, if there is no social desirability effect, y_i^D=y_i^S. So, we define the change in sensitive “Agree” as μ=y_i^S-y_i^D. To have a more precise analysis, we put our estimators into a regession to control geogrphical effects. The model is: 
y_i=〖βX〗_i+μS_i,{█(y_i=y_i^D  when S_i=0@y_i=y_i^S  when S_i=1)┤
Where, S_i (0,1) is the item-count list treatment and  X_i is a matrix of control covariates. We use State fixed-effect to control heterogenous COVID-19 confirmed cases by different states, and we also cluster standard errors at the State level. 
	[True fraction of sensitive “Agree”] =d ̅+μ
	[Percentage increase in sensitive “Agree”] =μ⁄d ̅ 

See the Chinese Virus Preregistration.pdf (https://osf.io/pv7zw/) for details.

outliers.value: An outlier is defined as being any point of data that lies over 1.5 IQRs below the first quartile (Q1) or above the third quartile (Q3)in the data set. We will compare and report the analytical results with and without outliers.

dependent.value:
a.	Social stigmatization. This construct is measured by asking whether or not the respondent agree with the statement, “Chinese immigrants damage the public health in the U.S.” It is a dichotomic variable (1=Agree, 0=Disagree). To filter the socially desirable responses, the statement is embedded in a list experiment. In the treatment group of the list experiment, we ask how many of the 4 listed statements (above statement included) do people agree with. In the control group of the list experiment, we ask how many of the 3 listed statements (above statement not included) do people agree with. The true support of the statement is the difference between the number of agreed statements in the treatment group and that in the control group.
b.	Social desirability bias. Social desirability bias will be detected through the analysis of the list experiment. See the Analyses Section for details. 
c.	Blame. This construct is measured by asking “overall, to what extent do you believe the federal government is deserving for blame for the current COVID-19/Chinese Virus outbreak?”. Responses are to be recorded on a 0-100 scale (0=Not at all to blame, 100=Completely to blame).

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions. There will be two experimental conditions for hypothesis testing. The intervention is to be delivered in terms of a vignette, which narrates the current situation of COVID-19 in the U.S. While keeping everything consistent, the vignette in the control group label the virus as COVID-19, and the virus name in the treatment group is manipulated as “Chinese Virus”. To measure social stigmatization, we will apply list experiment technique which further includes two conditions in each experimental condition. The control list experimental condition includes three controversial statements, while the treatment list experimental condition includes three same controversial statements plus one sensitive statement regarding social stigmatization.

hypothesis.value:
1)	Does mislabeling COVID-19 as “Chinese Virus” lead to social stigmatization against Chinese immigrants in the U.S.?
2)	Does mislabeling COVID-19 as “Chinese Virus” reduce the blameworthiness of the federal government in response to the pandemic?
We raise four hypotheses to be tested in this study:
H1a: The label “Chinese Virus” will lead to social stigmatization against Chinese immigrants in the U.S.
H1b: The label “Chinese Virus” justifies stigmatization and therefore will lead to less social desirability bias in answering the question regarding stigmatization.
H2: The label “Chinese Virus” will lead to less blame against the federal government in handling the pandemic.
H3: The effect of “Chinese Virus” is divided based on people’s partisanship.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name:
Social Cost and Political Gain: The Effect of Mislabeling COVID-19 as “Chinese Virus”
We examine whether mislabeling COVID-19 as "Chinese Virus" leads to 1) more social stigmatization; 2) less social pressure of stigmatization; 3) less blame toward the federal government.
registration_responses.other:
A.	Subgroup analysis
We will subgroup our sample into three groups: “Trump approve”, “Trump disapprove” and “Trump no opinion”. We will rerun the main analyses in each subgroup. 
B.	Covariate analysis
1.	[Blame] explain correlations between control variables and blame in the “blame model”. 
2.	[Direct] explain correlations between control variables and driect “Agree” in the “direct model”. 
3.	We will compare results for who passes or failed the manipulation check question. 
C.	Re-weighted analysis
We will weight our data with iterative proportional fitting technique (raking) to match the US population. We will compare results for the original data and the weighted data.
registration_responses.sample: We will stop data collection once 1,200 subjects (approximately 300 per cell) have submitted a response on MTurk. Deviations from this goal are entirely due to MTurk software and outside of our control.
registration_responses.analyses:
Our analysis separate in three parts: blame, social stigmatization, and social desirability effect. 
	Blame
	The Average Treatment effect (ATE) will be visualized by a difference-in-means graphic.
	State fixed effect linear model with control covariates and clustered standard errors at the State level (“blame model”). 
	Stigmatization (answering “Agree” in the sensitive statement)
	[Direct Question] We use difference-in-means to examine the Chinese Virus treatment effect on the direct question. We will also report the percentage of answering “Agree” in the direct question. Finally, we will report a logit regression model with covariates (“direct model”). 
	[List item count] We will report ATE with difference-in-means between the 4-item list and 3-item list in both control and Chinese Virus treatment groups. 
	Social desirability effect (Coffman et al. 2017)
We subgroup our sample by control and Chinese Virus treatment groups. The following analysis will be done in both groups. We will compare results for both groups. 
	[Change in sensitive “Agree”] We observe direct question answer as d_i (0,1), and 3-item count answer as c_i (between 0 to 3). We measure the sum of both questions as y_i^D=d_i+c_i. We measure the 4-item count answer with one sensitive statement as y_i^S (between 0 to 4). Ideally, if there is no social desirability effect, y_i^D=y_i^S. So, we define the change in sensitive “Agree” as μ=y_i^S-y_i^D. To have a more precise analysis, we put our estimators into a regession to control geogrphical effects. The model is: 
y_i=〖βX〗_i+μS_i,{█(y_i=y_i^D  when S_i=0@y_i=y_i^S  when S_i=1)┤
Where, S_i (0,1) is the item-count list treatment and  X_i is a matrix of control covariates. We use State fixed-effect to control heterogenous COVID-19 confirmed cases by different states, and we also cluster standard errors at the State level. 
	[True fraction of sensitive “Agree”] =d ̅+μ
	[Percentage increase in sensitive “Agree”] =μ⁄d ̅ 

See the Chinese Virus Preregistration.pdf (https://osf.io/pv7zw/) for details.
registration_responses.outliers: An outlier is defined as being any point of data that lies over 1.5 IQRs below the first quartile (Q1) or above the third quartile (Q3)in the data set. We will compare and report the analytical results with and without outliers.
registration_responses.dependent:
a.	Social stigmatization. This construct is measured by asking whether or not the respondent agree with the statement, “Chinese immigrants damage the public health in the U.S.” It is a dichotomic variable (1=Agree, 0=Disagree). To filter the socially desirable responses, the statement is embedded in a list experiment. In the treatment group of the list experiment, we ask how many of the 4 listed statements (above statement included) do people agree with. In the control group of the list experiment, we ask how many of the 3 listed statements (above statement not included) do people agree with. The true support of the statement is the difference between the number of agreed statements in the treatment group and that in the control group.
b.	Social desirability bias. Social desirability bias will be detected through the analysis of the list experiment. See the Analyses Section for details. 
c.	Blame. This construct is measured by asking “overall, to what extent do you believe the federal government is deserving for blame for the current COVID-19/Chinese Virus outbreak?”. Responses are to be recorded on a 0-100 scale (0=Not at all to blame, 100=Completely to blame).
registration_responses.conditions: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions. There will be two experimental conditions for hypothesis testing. The intervention is to be delivered in terms of a vignette, which narrates the current situation of COVID-19 in the U.S. While keeping everything consistent, the vignette in the control group label the virus as COVID-19, and the virus name in the treatment group is manipulated as “Chinese Virus”. To measure social stigmatization, we will apply list experiment technique which further includes two conditions in each experimental condition. The control list experimental condition includes three controversial statements, while the treatment list experimental condition includes three same controversial statements plus one sensitive statement regarding social stigmatization.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
1)	Does mislabeling COVID-19 as “Chinese Virus” lead to social stigmatization against Chinese immigrants in the U.S.?
2)	Does mislabeling COVID-19 as “Chinese Virus” reduce the blameworthiness of the federal government in response to the pandemic?
We raise four hypotheses to be tested in this study:
H1a: The label “Chinese Virus” will lead to social stigmatization against Chinese immigrants in the U.S.
H1b: The label “Chinese Virus” justifies stigmatization and therefore will lead to less social desirability bias in answering the question regarding stigmatization.
H2: The label “Chinese Virus” will lead to less blame against the federal government in handling the pandemic.
H3: The effect of “Chinese Virus” is divided based on people’s partisanship.

attributes.title: Team im Leben - Team im Sport (TILTIS)
attributes.description: We will examine how social exclusion and jealousy affect a persons mood.

q1.value: Effect of romantic jealousy on mood

q3.value: There is evidence, that social exclusion affects people's mood negatively. In this experiment, we will examine  how memories of romantic jealousy, solved/ discussed jealousy and exclusion by the partner in a romantic relationship act on mood.

q4.value: After recalling memories of jealousy, participants will feel worse than after recalling memories of solved or discussed jealousy, exclusion through the partner and happy moments in a romantic relationship.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Mixed design with 2 factors: pre and post measurements and type of exclusion (4 levels: memory of situation with jealousy, memory of situation where feelings of jealousy where solved or dicussed, memory of situation with social exclusion by the partner, memory of the last positive activity together/ control group)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit heterosexual adults who are currently in a romantic relationship. They must be in the relationship for at least 6 months. Participants will be recruited by using the mailing list of the psychology student association and social media as well as through verbal communication. Under all participants, we will give away a cinema gift card.

q13.value: Our target sample size is a minimum of 128 participants. However, we will recruite more participants if possible.

question.value: We create four conditions in the description of a memory : memory of a situation with jealousy, memory of a situation where feelings of jealousy where solved or dicussed, memory of a situation with exclusion by the partner, memory of the last positive activity together/ control group

We will measure a few demographic variables, relationship satisfaction, jealousy (trait), communication quality, attachment style, jealousy (state), self worth, perceived control and mood with scales. Mood is our primary outcome variable. We will capture it before and after the manipulation with the PANAS scale. The scale includes 10 negative affect- items and 10 positive affect- items and the answers range from 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely).

First, descriptive statistics will be calculated to provide an overview of the data. The second step is to visualize the data. Then, we will do a ANOVA with repeated measures and a  within- between- interaction. After that, we will do a post-hoc test.
